# Chapter 19

Rick hauled himself upright from a heap of upturned banisters, his lab coat streaked with spectral nacho cheese and interdimensional indignity. “Morty! Deadpool! Heads up—we’ve gone full M.C. Escher, and I’m pretty sure the painting’s drunk.” He punched settings on his portal gun; neon arcs jolted through stairwells that twisted, melted, or defied gravity altogether.

A stair morphed into a glossy slide beneath Morty’s feet. He pinwheeled into Deadpool, arms flailing. “Aw geez, Rick! Since when do stairs have vendettas? This better not be because you roasted MC Hammer that one time.”

Deadpool caught him and barely budged. “Relax! Worst case, we end up in a Dalí landscape and I get to suplex a melting clock. Trust me, pain is temporary, surrealist shame is forever.”

A pulse rolled through the world like bad reverb. Meta-Master’s voice twisted from everywhere: “You idiots are just punchlines waiting to drop. Keep bantering—your demise only gets funnier! I own the pen. Reality’s my doodle pad!”

Rick, unbothered, aimed at a corkscrewing stair. “Your handwriting’s as bad as your patter, you hack! I’ve triangulated memes funnier than your whole personality. Keep monologuing, meta-boy—I’m tracking your signal.”

Morty gripped his own portal gun, knuckles bone-white. “Meta-humor can’t just, like… erase us, can it? We don’t dissolve if the jokes go flat, right?”

Deadpool twirled a katana, eyes bright. “Only if you take yourself seriously, kid. And you’re in the presence of an Olympic-level irreverence champion.”

Suddenly, the floor snapped into a single full-page comic panel—hard outlines, word balloons drifting airily. The world flickered: watercolor, pixels, glossy photorealism, back to pulp. Rick staggered, swearing. “Reality’s coming apart at the seams! If this keeps up, we’ll end up as sticky notes in a freshman’s dorm.”

Deadpool grinned. “Been there, punched that. Time to bust every wall I see—fourth, fifth, whatever.”

They sprinted as the stairs crumbled into blank margins behind them. Every step twisted physics: risers spitting punchlines, handrails looping Möbius-style, elevator doors popping open with laugh tracks, then slamming shut.

Morty’s shoelaces tied and untied themselves. “Which way is up?! My legs are negotiating with my knees and losing!” He tripped—Deadpool yanked him back just before a banister unraveled into flat panel borders.

“Mental health and impossible stairs follow the same rule,” Deadpool intoned. “Just keep moving. And never look down.”

Above, Meta-Master cackled and spray-painted “HA! UPPER STORY, GET IT?” across the spinning sky. The walls warped into a cosmic Etch-a-Sketch, doodles blurring into the melting cosmos.

Rick reloaded his portal gun with a glowing cartridge. “Meta-humor’s mangling the rules. Straight-men get it worst—we’ll be rebooted as sock puppets, or, god forbid, a gritty origin miniseries. I snoozed through your last one, Morty.”

Morty groaned. “Last reboot, I had a mullet. Never again.”

Deadpool dropped onto a floating railing with a soggy *splat*, hanging by one hand. “This is like my psyche—twisted, self-aware, often missing a step. Still beats group therapy.”

A clown portrait winked back, echoing Deadpool’s older hallucinations. The banister squirmed, and Rick yanked the merc free with a slapstick “pop!”

“Only you break walls hard enough to get paperwork for it,” Rick muttered, recalibrating as he eyed a flickering EXIT sign that blinked “META-NARRATIVE RESOLUTION”—the sort that never means safety.

Morty’s voice cracked. “The stairs are arguing over who gets custody of the landing! What do we do?”

Deadpool squeezed Morty’s shoulder. “Reality’s flexible. Dance along—and never skip on the tip jar. Worst case scenario: the multiverse gets a headache.”

Meta-Master’s voice boomed, garbled: “The multiverse spins on its punchlines. You’re trapped until someone nails the ultimate joke!”

Rick cocked an eyebrow at Deadpool—a challenge, half-mad, half-admiring. “If laughs are our ammo, let’s go thermonuclear. Get unserious—fast—or we disappear.”

Deadpool tipped an imaginary hat. “Born for this, Rick. Let’s weaponize some comedy. Real murder’s off-limits—thanks, Squirrel Girl.”

Morty’s heart hammered. “Sure, no pressure. Just gotta be funnier than reality’s collapse.”

They squared their shoulders—the very picture of absurd heroics. Deadpool crouched low, peering down a stairwell spiraling through three impossible directions. “I have vertigo in places I didn’t know had nerves,” he muttered, sheathing a katana just to flip off a clown portrait—a bookend to his multiversal debut.

Rick, defying the rules of gravity, time, and taste, jerked his thumb at a bucking ceiling—maybe the floor—where a glowing arch beckoned. “Ignore the existential nausea. Just head for the light and pray we don’t get rebooted as ‘Calvin & Dobbs.’”

Morty stumbled after. “Swear to me we’ll never speak of this if we survive. Like that time with horse-Beth—nobody ever brings it up.”

Deadpool grinned behind his mask. “If we live, I’m pitching this as a musical. Smile for the variant covers!”

They bolted for the exit as the world laughed, everything unraveling behind them. For one beat, they were perfectly in synch—not just survivors of chaos, but a team, forged in white-hot meta-madness.

**End of Chapter 19**
